catalogDescription: Inputs, processing, outputs, and files of several transaction-processing subsystems. Foundation for understanding internal control. Variety of tools used to design, create, or document accounting information systems (AIS) to achieve organizational objectives.
courseDescription: Explores business processes and data flows through organizations. Examines control environment from corporate and information systems perspectives. Assesses risks and controls to mitigate those risks. Focuses on management information needs and their role as organizational stakeholders.
coursePurpose: Provide accounting professionals with information, skills, and insights to use, manage, and evaluate information systems that provide reliable and timely information to organizational stakeholders. Material based on professional standards: COBIT and COSO.
courseGoals: Understand the transaction processing systems that are common to most businesses
Understand the control environment and control frameworks relevant to an accounting information system

competenciesAndLearningOutcomes.competency: Analyze a set of business processes and report control deficiencies
competenciesAndLearningOutcomes.evaluation: Cycle reports, homework, quizzes, and exams

competenciesAndLearningOutcomes.competency: Learn how to evaluate the appropriateness of various controls
Learn data visualization and Excel to support accounting decision making
Communicate effectively both in writing and in presentations
competenciesAndLearningOutcomes.evaluation: Cycle presentations, cycle reports, and data visualizations

competenciesAndLearningOutcomes.competency: Develop the Christlike attributes necessary to work in teams
Serve the community by applying the principles taught in class
Learn how integrity and accountability are important spiritual and accounting principles

participation: Expected for all students. Come prepared with thoughtful questions. Read assigned material before class. Challenge material and apply to live scenarios.
